name: Advanced Scenario - Equation
description: Advanced Scenario - Equation establishes persistence by setting up autostart during boot or logon, and uses Guardrails to evade defensive measures. then it places an obfuscated command into a registry key. This action is followed by executing this command from a registry key. Then it discovers peripheral devices by enumerating drivers, and, finally, creates a hidden file system.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 32
description: Advanced Scenario - APT 32 initiates its attack by downloading and executing a VBA script. It then proceeds to execute commands using the Windows Event Log, downloads a file from the internet, and executes a batch script. APT 32 creates persistence in the registry run keys and verifies the success of the created persistence. Then attempts to discover domain admins, steal credentials from the local machine, and use them to attempt lateral movement. It also maps admin shares, logs key inputs, discovers the file and directory structure, receives system information, encrypts files, and compresses and exfiltrates data in parallel. Finally, it lists credential files stored in current user AppData folders, performs DLL Search Order Hijacking, enumerates non-default installed applications, installs and runs a service, and creates a new user.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Qakbot
description:
The advanced scenario Qakbot involves a malicious software program executing a DLL file to gain unauthorized access to a system. 
The program then proceeds to discover the configuration of the local system, create persistence through the use of a local scheduled task, identify local and domain groups and power users, and perform enumeration of the domain controller (DC).

The tool then attempts to access the DC through remote desktop protocol (RDP), steal credentials from local system, which then are used to remotely access and run commands on a remote host. The program also lists any installed security software and uses ADFind to gather additional relevant information.
author: Cymulate

name: Top Data Exfiltration - Techniques By Cymulate 2022
description:
The template contains the following top 2022 methods for data exfiltration:
Exfiltration Over DNS, Exfiltration using PSFTP, HTTP Data Exfiltration from String (XOR Encrypted), HTTP (Data Hidden in Cookie) Data Exfiltration from String, TELNET Data Exfiltration from String, Exchange Exfiltration using Basic HTTP Request, Webupload, Git Exfiltration (Windows)
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - REvil
description: Advanced Scenario REvil starts with downloading and running VBscript as a phishing attachment, then downloads and executes a file with WMIC, then it compiles and runs an executable file from a variable in an environment variable, using native API, Then it enumerates passwords from Powershell history file and looks for interesting keywords in that file. It uses 3'rd party tool to prevent the machine from shutdown, runs mimikatz to steal credentials and performs privilege escalation to SYSTEM. It, then, modifies the registry and verifies the success of modification, it impedes defense software, deletes the prefetch files, and some folders, masquerades its executables to match legitimate files, decodes encoded executables and runs them, enumerates power groups, folders and files and performs general recon of information, usable for export, exfiltrates system information and encrypts files. Finally, it stops services and deletes shadow copies.
author: Cymulate

name: Top Credential Dumping - Techniques By Cymulate 2022
description:
The template contains the following top 2022 methods for credentials dumping:
Create Volume Shadow Copy with WMI
Registry dump of LSA secrets
Registry dump of SAM, creds, and secrets
Dump *All* credentials using all LaZagne methods availiable (Windows)
DCSync using Mimikatz (All users)
DCSync using packed Mimikatz (64)
Powershell DPAPI Unprotect (decrypt) data from file
Dump SPN user's hash with Kerberoasting
Kerberos ticket with unconstrained delegation
SpoolSample : tool to coerce Windows hosts authenticate to other machines via the MS-RPRN RPC interface
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Quantum Ransomware Affiliate Intrusion
description:
Quantom ransomware is typically deployed by ransomware affiliates using the initial access of the Emotet malware. This malicious software is designed to encrypt data on a computer, making it inaccessible to the owner. Once the data is encrypted, a ransom note is displayed, usually demanding a payment in exchange for a decryption key.

Emotet malware, is typically delivered through a malicious email attachment or link. Once the malicious file is opened, it will be deployed onto the system, allowing the ransomware to be delivered by ransomware affiliates.

The ransom message will include instructions for making a payment, usually in the form of a cryptocurrency such as Bitcoin, as well as details on what the payment will provide the victim. Typically, this includes a decryption key that will allow the user to regain access to their data.

First the victim runs the ISO file and clicks on the LNK file inside.
That in turn will launch an encoded powershell script that uses Regsvr32 to load a local DLL and executes it.

Next the attacker will attempt to persist in the machine by modifying the registry run key.

The attackers will then install AnyDesk on the machine to achieve additional persistency.

The attackers  will attempt to use Zero Logon on the domain controller which upon success will launch mimikatz.

Then the attackers use Process Injection to run another DLL file into memory.

The attackers will try to hide their artifacts by deleting them from the system.

On the next step the attackers will use ADFind to enumerate AD Groups.

The attackers will then preform various domain, system, shares and network discovery operations.

The attackers will use SoftPerfect IP Scanner to scan the network.

The attackers will attempt to dump LSASS using ProcDump and exfiltrate it to an SFTP server using rclone.

The attackers will attempt to RDP to a machine.

The attackers will prevent the system from shutting down and logging off using DontSleep.exe.

Finally, the attackers will deploy ransomware on the machine.
author: Cymulate

name: OKTA Administrative activity
description: Simulates administrative activity on OKTA platform to create suspicious activity by creating a new user, creating a new group, adding the user to a group, and enrolling the new user to the SMS factor.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Zirconium
description: Advanced Scenario Zirconium uses obfuscated files, attempts credential theft with an external resource(online tool), runs an .msi executor, modifies registry Run keys to establish persistence and checks for a successful execution. It also tries to perform DSync attack on a domain controller with the obtained user credentials and parallel to that creates yet another persistence with logon script. It obtains system information, encodes it and exfiltrates over HTTP. It executes remote payload with javascript and masquerades its executables for legitimate files.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 28
description: Advanced Scenario APT 28 Starts with dropping and executing MS Office macro-containing file and hides previously dropped file with attrib. It modifies registry Run keys to obtain persistence, runs commands in a hidden window, performs password spray. Attempts obtaining NTLN hash and perform Pass-the-Hash attack with Mimikatz, uses powershell to drop on disk malicious files and web-shell, executes a .dll file with RunDll32, enumerates users and accounts and escalates privileges using a known tool.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 34 (OilRig)
description:
OilRig is a suspected Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern and international victims since at least 2014.
The group has targeted a variety of sectors, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications, the group carries out supply chain attacks, leveraging the trust relationship between organizations to attack their primary targets.
The intrusion begins with a spear phishing attachment arriving in an email. Upon initial access, the attackers begin utilizing PowerShell to execute Scheduled tasks to gain persistence, then loads custom tools by injecting .NET assembly into memory, the PowerShell commands are encoded with base64, then tools for sandbox or Virtual machine detection are used, it performs various discovery and exfiltration activities and exfiltrates via DNS based C2 communication
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Charming Kittens (Magic Hound)
description: Advanced Scenario Charming kittens starts with downloading and running a vbs script. Downloads a file from an external source, using PowerShell, runs a command in a hidden window, modifies the registry, and runs an encrypted command from within it, then starts a keylogger. Finally, it obtains system information, compresses it, and exfiltrates it as XOR-encrypted file.
author: Cymulate

name: Kubernetes - Host IPC Privilege (GCP)
description: Kubernetes - Host IPC Privilege (GCP)
author: Cymulate

name: Azure - Password Spray (Reporting Endpoint) to Database Access
description: This scenario performs a password spray attack for a given username list and a chosen password and proceeds to use the detected credentials and attempt accessing a target Azure SQL database and run an arbitrary SQL query on it remotely.
author: Cymulate

name: Log4j Internal Scanner - Windows
description: This template uses a custom scanner to scan for log4j vulnerability in windows environments internally
author: Cymulate

name: Gap Analysis Template
description: Gap Analysis Template
author: Cymulate

name: Basic Windows Tests
description: Run basic Windows security checks to assess the security posture of Windows machines' configurations and and the Windows domain environment.
author: Cymulate

name: MacOS Basic Tests
description: Run basic MacOS security checks to assess the security posture of Linux machines' configurations.
author: Cymulate

name: Basic Linux Tests
description: Run basic Linux security checks to assess the security posture of Linux machines' configurations.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - TA505 (CL0P)
description:
TA505 - "Clop" (sometimes stylized as "Cl0p") has been one of the most prolific ransomware families in the past three years. It has gained infamy for compromising high-profile organizations in various industries worldwide using multilevel extortion techniques that resulted in huge payouts estimated at US$500 million.
The actor initially accesses the machine using a spear-phishing attachment containing a malicious macro.
Creates persistency by abusing the port monitors registry key.
Using bypass technique UAC WSReset.
Attempts to tamper with Windows Defender using the registry.
Decrypt files on the workstation.
Runs various discovery commands to discover files and directories.
Runs a network sweep to perform network discovery.
Enables RDP on the infected workstation and attempts to use it to connect to another server.
Dumps SQL data from an SQL server and attempts to exfiltrate it through HTTP.
Finally, the actor drops a WebShell on the infected machine.
The actor initially access the machine using a spear phishing attachment containing a malicious macro.

Then the actor creates persistency by abusing the port monitors registry key.

Then the actors bypass using UAC using WSReset
The actors then attempts to tamper with Windows Defender using the registry.

The actor then attempts to decrypt files on the workstation.

The actor then runs various discovery commands to discover files and directories.

Additionally the actor runs a network sweep to perform network discovery.

The actor enables RDP on the infected workstation and attempts to use it to connect to another server.

The actor dumps SQL data from an SQL server and attempts to exfiltrate it through HTTP.

Finally the actor drops a webshell on the infected machine.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Indrik Spider (Evil Corp)
description:
Indrik Spider (Evil Corp) is responsible for the distribution of various Ransomware strains such as BitPaymer and WastedLocker. Additionally, this group is responsible for the distribution of the Dridex trojan.

The intrusion begins with a phishing email with a malicious attachment, after execution the actor runs recon commands using PowerShell.
Next, a scheduled job is started and the registry run keys are modified for persistence.
Next, the actor tampers with Windows Defender.
Mimikatz is executed to steal credentials. 
The actor then runs various discovery CMDlets and executes ADFind.
For the lateral movement, the actor executes PSexec.
Then the actor dumps LSASS, and exfiltrates it using a C2.
Finally, ransomware is deployed on the workstation.
author: Cymulate

name: KrbRelayUp(Universal no fix LPE) to Domain Admin
description: This template abuse default ADCS configuration by requesting the DC machine account certificate. then the template performs pass-the-ticket attack using rubeus and eventually elevating our privileges using dcsync.
author: Cymulate

name: KrbRelayUp(No fix Universal LPE) to Lateral Movement
description: the template will use krbrelayup(universal no fix lpe) to elevate the privileges of the current user to system and then perform a mimikatz dump to collect credentials. once credentials has been obtained the credentials will be passed and be used to check where the current user have access to and perform lateral movement to those targets.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenarios - MuddyWater APT
description:
MuddyWater is an Iranian threat group that has primarily targeted Middle Eastern nations, and has also targeted European and North American nations. The group's victims are mainly in the telecommunications, government (IT services), and oil sectors. 

The intrusion starts with a phishing email which an attachment that leads to Script execution or installation of ScreenConnect Remote Administration tool. The actors then use WMI to launch local processes. Additionally a scheduled task is launched to gain persistence.
The actors extract passwords using Lazagne.
The actors disable Windows Defender using CMD.
The actors use Steganography for Defense Evasion. 
The actors will dump LSASS and LSA secrets for Credential Access. 
The actors will run a variety of discovery cmdlets. 
The actors will exfiltrate data by archiving it and extracting it over the standard HTTP protocol.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Cobalt Group
description:
Cobalt Group Advanced scenario starts with downloading a phishing attachment, written in VBS. Then it'll place it into the Start-Up folder and execute it from there. It will establish persistence by creating an on-startup task job, which is programmed for running the same VBS file. It will also attempt to create a Windows service with the task of running that file.
 Then it will list security products and attempt ingress tool transfer by downloading a file with certutil. The action will be followed by privilege escalation of bypassing UAC and modifying the registry, so it'll run the previously downloaded file. After that, it'll attempt remote file execution with Regsvr32.
 Then it'll attempt a port scan with Nmap and RDP into one of the found servers. Finally, it'll create an exfiltration folder, compress data, found during Nmap scan, and exfiltrate it over HTTP and over DNS.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Sandworm for Linux
description: Sandworm for Linux Advanced Scenario starts with establishing an ssh tunnel, proceeds to disable history collection, then scenario disables the firewall. Then it tests the usage of the uncommonly used port. Then it masquerades a user process for a Kernel process. Then it collects system information, encodes it, and exfiltrates it over HTTP ***NOTE***This scenario contains distro-specific executions, that might not work on other distros
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Lapsus$ for AWS
description: Lapsus$ Advanced Scenario for AWS starts with downloading and executing phishing attachment, Then it queries the web for a specific tool, creates a folder for future exfiltration, searchers for AWS credentials and, if found, uses them to execute a custom command on one of Windows-based instances. The command includes downloading and unpacking a masqueraded mimikatz. Then it creates an IAM user and enumerates S3 buckets. Parallel to that all passwords are collected from history file, then compressed and exfiltrated over HTTP. The file, containing collected passwords in encrypted with AES to simulate data encryption. Then EC2 instances are being enumerated with following attempt of accessing one of them via RDP. At the end desktop background is defaced to simulate defacing action. ***NOTE***This scenario will run completely only if the tested instance connected via ssm agent
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Lapsus$ for Azure
description: Lapsus$ Advanced Scenario for Azure starts with downloading and executing phishing attachment, Then it queries the web for a specific tool, creates a folder for future exfiltration, then it collects all relevant to Azure passwords from history file, compresses them and exfiltrates over HTTP. Then itll try to authenticate to Azure, enumerate Windows-based instances, create Azure AD user, RDP to one of found instances and run a script on one of them with Run command. The script includes downloading and unpacking masqueraded mimikatz file and querying the web for specific information. It also will try to exfiltrate a calc.exe file from the instance. At the end desktop background is defaced to simulate defacing action.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Lockbit 2.0 Ransomware Intrusion
description:
LockBit ransomware is malicious software designed to block user access to computer systems in exchange for a ransom payment. LockBit will automatically vet for valuable targets, spread the infection, and encrypt all accessible computer systems on a network. This ransomware is used for highly targeted attacks against enterprises and other organizations.

Lockbit arrives via spam email or by brute forcing insecure RDP or VPN credentials.
The phishing attachment would execute various scripting languages on the machine.
The actors will attempt to persist on the machine by using Boot Or Logon Initialization scripts.
The actors will attempt to use DLL Side-Loading.
The actors will attempt to gain higher privileges using Access Token Manipulation.
The actors will attempt to disable security solutions.
The actors will dump credentials and scan the network to perform lateral movement.
The actors will using mimikatz to collect credentials and exfiltrate them using HTTP.
The actors will perform network share discovery using Powershell.
The actors will attempt to use Advanced IP Scanner to perform network scans.
Finally, the actors will deploy ransomware on the attacked machine.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Sandworm for Windows
description:
Sandworm advanced scenario starts with downloading a phishing attachment and then runs a vbs script from that attachment.
 Then it uses WMI to download a file with PowerShell, then it writes a web-shell on the disk. It creates an admin user on SQL server, it creates a new SMB share for anonymous access.
 Then it discovers domains within the organization, attempts password spray and RDP connection to one of them. Then it attempts execution of a command with run32.dll and tries to install a keylogger, following by keystrokes capture.
 Then, it enumerates all local and domain users, compresses the data and exfiltrates with C2 channel. Parallel to that it encrypts a file in temp folder to simulate data encryption. Then, it deletes Event Viewer logs.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Cuba Ransomware Intrusion
description:
UNC2596, a threat actor that deploys COLDDRAW ransomware, publicly known as Cuba Ransomware.
Cuba ransomware begins by initiating a scheduled task on the target endpoint and drop a webshell that will be deployed on it.
The actors will attempt various actions to finalize their attack:
Enumerate all accounts on the system and exfiltrate them using DNS.
Attempt to detect if the system is a Virtual Machine
Attempt to execute a signed variant of Mimikatz will be executed.
Add a new account to a local group within the endpoint.
Use Process Injection to bypass defenses.
Utilize a bug in an Avast driver to terminate processes from the kernel.
Grant themselves access to all shares using net share.
Ping sweep the network for discovery purposes.
Use Lazagne to drop credentials from browsers.
Exfiltrate all the data dumped during the intrusion using PSFTP.
Attempt to use RDP for lateral movement.
Kill services by killing their corresponding processes.
Finally, a Ransomware variant is executed on the machine.
A mandatory system restart is required to fully remove the Avast driver sys file which will be located in the preferred location (default: Windows temp folder within the following path 'windows\avast').
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Wizard Spider Intrusion
description:
This Intrusion mimics a real intrusion by Wizard Spider which deployed Diavol Ransomware.
Wizard spider perform internal discovery using Windows utilities, execute lateral movement using AnyDesk and RDP, dump credentials multiple ways, exfiltrate data and deploy domain wide ransomware.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - Fin7
description:
Fin7 Advanced scenario will start with Downloading a VBS script as a spearphishing attachment and executing it from a startup folder.
Then it'll perform a web request with Powershell to simulate the download of a file and then it'll encode a simple string and execute it from the registry while creating the necessary key, thus setting persistency.
It'll also perform additional persistency settings, such as creating a task job and running the mshta executor.
Then, it'll perform kerberosting, and then it'll scan for a ZeroLogon vulnerability.
After this, the scenario will create new shim database files, which will be followed by lateral movement activities, such as: invoking the VNC injector, discovering and connecting to a remote host via RDP.
After that, it'll collect information such as: doc files, screenshots, video captures and system information
That action will be followed by archiving the obtained information and exfiltrating it over a DNS. 
At the final stage, the archived file will be encrypted with the AES256 algorithm to simulate ransomware activity
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 33
description: APT 33 starts with a spear-phishing attack of an excel with an embedded macro. It creates a shortcut in Start folders, then sets persistence via WMI Event Subscription. Then it executes an obfuscated PowerShell command and uses LaZagne tool to extract all possible credentials. Following that it compresses it with Winrar and exfiltrates with multiple ways. Then it enumerates domain users and performs password spraying, attempting to log into the discovered users.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 38 for Windows
description: APT 38 for Windows performs a spearphishing, executes a command as a service, while creating a taskjob with that command for further use, stops Microsoft firewall, tampers with Defender Registry, clears Event logs, captures inputs with keylogger and then exfiltrates information, encoded with XOR. Finally it obtains system information and encrypts resulting file with AES to simulate data encryption, performed by APT 38 in the wild.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 38 for Linux
description: APT 38 for Linux drops a web shell file into a default folder of Apache Tomcat and Parallel to that attempts an RCE on Apache Strus 2 application. Upon successful execution of the RCE, an executable will be downloaded. An executable, in turn, deletes bash history for current shell and adds a whoami command to cron of root user. It also adds to cron commands of creating and deleting 10 empty files, to simulate disk wipe, performed by APT 38 in the wild.
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT Lazarus
description: APT Lazarus performs spearphishing, downloads and executes a file, while performing multiple persistence setting and defense evasion actions, such as: modifying registry, hiding files and creating dynamic links(shortcuts). Then it queries for a specific registry values, enumerates domain users and attempts to brute force their credentials. It also attempts to access SMB shares and Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement, for that reason it modifies defence system (such as firewall) rules. In addition it uses a keylogger for collecting information, which is later on exfiltrated with custom encryption. It attempts Command and Control activities through a remote connection. Finally it stops vital services on the attacked machines.
author: Cymulate

name: XLoader Cross-platform RAT
description: Template which attempts to successfully emulate XLoader on a Windows platform
author: Cymulate

name: Advanced Scenario - APT 29
description: APT29 performs network configuration discovery, disables windows firewall, performs a UAC bypass, uses different abilities of mimikatz while bypassing PowerShell AMSI, downloads and masquerades AdFind as csrss.exe, then uses it to create a task job and pull out relevant information from the domain, then it performs kerberosting and pass-the-ticket attacks, finally, it compresses data and exfiltrates it over HTTPS.
author: Cymulate

name: Resource Based Constrained Delegation to Domain Admin
description: this template assumes that the curent user have GenericWrite privilege over a computer object. it will query the domain to make sure its possible to add a new computer to the domain, add it and then with the write privileges on the vulenrable machine it will allow the newly created machine to perform actions on behalf of that computer. then it will request a TGS for a high privilege account to compromise the domain.
author: Cymulate

name: ZeroLogon to Enterprise Admin
description: This template will scan for the ZeroLogon vulnerability if vulnerable will run the exploit and proceed to DCSync on the current domain Grab the Krbtgt enumerate the parent forest and attempt to escalate to the root domain.
author: Cymulate

name: Kubernetes service account to cluster admin
description: This Module will attempt to search if the current user can extract the default service account token, mount it and then dump secrets with the current privs. once dumped, the module will try to escalate to by dumping the kube-system secrets resulting in cluster admin privs
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: IAM manipulation + hiding logs
description:
Mimics malicious behavior in an attempt of gaining persistence while evading defense mechanisms.
The scenario includes stopping Cloudtrail, creation of an IAM user, enumerating IAM groups with administrator permissions, adding the created user into one of them, and then starting Cloudtrail service again.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: Spinning malicious instance
description:
Spins an instance, mimicking an attacker attempting to gain persistence by placing a malicious instance in an AWS account.
The scenario includes the creation, modification, and attachment of a Security group and the creation of an instance from a preconfigured image on Amazon Marketplace.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: AMI deletion
description: Removes an Amazon Machine Image from your account, mimicking destructive attack action. The scenario includes the creation of an AMI from an AWS instance and then deleting it.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: IAM user added to admin group
description:
Adds an IAM user to the IAM group with high permissions.
The scenario includes creating an IAM user, Enumerating groups with administrative rights on your account, and adding the created user into one of them.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: Instance theft
description:
Allows downloading an instance as an ova container in order to perform further breaching activities. As an example-mounting an instance to a Virtual Machine as a disk and placing malicious content into it.
The scenario includes creating an S3 bucket, granting it the needed level of permissions, and downloading one of the instances to the bucket.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: Security groups manipulation
description: Manipulates the Security group in your account. The scenario contains creating a security group, modifying it, and attaching it to a running instance. Certain inputs must be provided by the customer.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: Object substitution
description: Substitutes an object in a given S3 bucket. The scenario includes placing a file into S3 bucket of choice and then substituting it with another file, that has the same name but contains an embedded macro.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: EC2 Non-authenticated custom script
description: Allows running an arbitrary script on an AWS instance, without authentication. The scenario includes updating a Linux instance, installing the curl tool, downloading and running a bash script. The instance must be provided by the customer. This scenario will only work if AWS SSM is installed on the instance.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS: Account take-over via Lambda invocation
description:
Mimics an account takeover, using Lambda function.
The scenario includes adding trust relations, that allows service to perform role assumption, creating Lambda function, attaching required trust relations to the function, permitting 3rd party account invocation of that function, and, finally creating/deleting or modifying an IAM user by invoking the function from the 3'rd party account.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS Lambda Functions
description: Basic validations of AWS Lambda functions. Includes creation, deletion, and account manipulations with Lambda functions. Some executions require additional configuration or prerequisites in terms of permissions and roles. This can be achieved by manual configuration or by pairing them with executions, dealing with those prerequisites.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS Infrastructure, VPC and Network
description: Basic validations of AWS infrastructure, VPC, and networks. Includes a variety of manipulations with security, network, permissions, backup, and logging elements.
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS S3 basic validations
description: AWS S3 basic validations. Includes configuration, and permissions manipulations with S3 buckets,
author: Cymulate

name: CSPM - AWS IAM basic validations
description: Basic validations of AWS IAM service. Includes testing functionalities of a user, group, and permission manipulation.
author: Cymulate

name: Windows: Malicious SMB Traffic to the Internet
description:
SMB is a file, printer, and serial port sharing protocol for Windows machines on the same network or domain. Adversaries may use SMB to interact with file shares, allowing them to move laterally throughout a network.
The traffic will be generated whether the user used is a local administrator on the remote machine or not.
Snort rule example: 1-24008
author: Cymulate
group: Malicious Network Traffic for IPS Assessments

name: Windows: Malicious Traffic to the Internet
description:
The Windows Component Object Model (COM) is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces. Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE). Distributed COM (DCOM) is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of COM beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.
The traffic will be generated whether the user used is a local administrator on the remote machine or not.
Snot rule example for DCOM traffic detection: https://www.snort.org/rule_docs/1-42185
author: Cymulate
group: Malicious Network Traffic for IPS Assessments

name: Windows: Lateral Movement Traffic over SMB
description:
SMB is a file, printer, and serial port sharing protocol for Windows machines on the same network or domain. Adversaries may use SMB to interact with file shares, allowing them to move laterally throughout a network.
The traffic will be generated whether the user used is a local administrator on the remote machine or not.
Snort rule example: 1-24008
author: Cymulate
group: Malicious Network Traffic for IPS Assessments

name: Windows: Lateral movement Traffic over DCOM
description:
The Windows Component Object Model (COM) is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces. Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE). Distributed COM (DCOM) is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of COM beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.
The traffic will be generated whether the user used is a local administrator on the remote machine or not.
Snot rule example for DCOM traffic detection: https://www.snort.org/rule_docs/1-42185
author: Cymulate
group: Malicious Network Traffic for IPS Assessments
